author: Chris Hine
title: Blackhawks counting on some new faces to blend in this season
text:
Much like after the Blackhawks won the Stanley Cup in 2010, general manager Stan Bowman has had to go about remaking the roster because of salary-cap constraints this offseason. One of the main differences between that roster makeover and this one is this time Bowman got a few more NHL-ready players in return.
The Hawks aren't so much rebuilding as they are reloading in the hopes of keeping their Cup window open.
Several new faces will play significant roles this season. Here's a look.
Trevor Daley , defenseman: The Hawks acquired Daley, 31, who has two years remaining on his contract, in the deal that sent Patrick Sharp and defensive prospect Stephen Johns to the Stars. Daley's addition offset the loss of Johnny Oduya, who signed with the Stars in free agency. Daley's possession numbers are not on the level with the Hawks' top three defensemen â€” Duncan Keith, Niklas Hjalmarsson and Brent Seabrook, but Daley is known more for his offensive prowess. He scored a career-high 16 goals last season, including six on the power play.
Artem Anisimov , center: One of three new Russians on the team, Anisimov, 27, came over in the trade that sent Brandon Saad to the Blue Jackets. Bowman was so high on Anisimov that he immediately gave him an extension through 2021 to be the second-line center the Hawks have sought for years. The Hawks hope Anisimov will mesh well with Patrick Kane, who said he prefers left-handed centers like Anisimov. Anisimov had 22 goals two seasons ago.
Artemi Panarin , winger: The Hawks were one of several teams vying for the services of Panarin, 23, who spent the last four seasons in the KHL developing into a dynamic scorer. Panarain was injured much of training camp, but his contract included an out clause that would allow him to go back to Russia if he did not make the team. Regardless, the Hawks like his playmaking ability.

(Chris Hine) Viktor Tikhonov , winger: Tikhonov, 27, is the grandson of the famous Russian national team coach and was a member of the Coyotes organization before going to the KHL to refine his game. He and Panarin played on the same team last season and he and Anisimov serve as interpreter for Panarin, who is just learning to speak English. Tikhonov is expected to play on the bottom two lines.
Ryan Garbutt , winger: The Hawks also acquired Garbutt, 30, in the Sharp trade with the Stars, retaining half of his $1.8 million cap hit. Garbutt has looked good through the preseason, using his speed to mesh well with the Hawks' style. He's a bottom-six winger who possesses some of the same skills and provocative attitude as Andrew Shaw and Andrew Desjardins. In that way Garbutt may seem a bit redundant on the roster. Garbutt is looking to rebound from an eight-goal performance last season after scoring 17 two seasons ago.
